citations.narrative:
In an enclosure housing two adult squirrel monkeys, there was a blue plastic tarp covering approximately 1/3 of the roof of
the enclosure. The torn plastic edges of the tarp appeared to be outside of the cage, but a facility representative reported
that pieces of plastic have been found within the enclosure itself. The squirrel moneys were climbing around the
enclosure. Plastic foreign material can be ingested, posing a potential risk to the health of the animals. The facility must
ensure the primary enclosures protect the nonhuman primates from injury.
Correct by: 08/23/2023.

In a white-fronted Amazon parrot's primary enclosure, there was a piece of sheet metal flashing (approximately 4” wide)
wrapped around the top of the nest box where the bird was actively climbing around on. The top edge of the metal was
covered but the bottom edge was loose, leaving a visible gap (approximately 1/2" wide). Sharp edges can cause injury to
the bird. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp
edges that could injure the birds.
Correct by: 8/27/2023.

There were several discarded cages, farm equipment, and other discarded items on the grounds of the area near the
maintenance sheds in the back area. The peacocks at the facility are free-roaming and have access to all areas. There
were at least three peacocks observed walking or resting under these areas of clutter at the time of inspection. Discarded
matter can cause injury to the free-ranging animals as well as serve as living areas for rodents and other pests. The
facility must ensure the premises where housing facilities are located, including surrounding grounds, are kept clean to
facilitate proper animal husbandry and sanitation.
Correct by: 9/5/2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Lynh Ly, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.80(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In an enclosure housing two adult squirrel monkeys, there was a blue plastic tarp covering approximately 1/3 of the roof of 
the enclosure. The torn plastic edges of the tarp appeared to be outside of the cage, but a facility representative reported 
that pieces of plastic have been found within the enclosure itself. The squirrel moneys were climbing around the 
enclosure. Plastic foreign material can be ingested, posing a potential risk to the health of the animals. The facility must 
ensure the primary enclosures protect the nonhuman primates from injury.  
Correct by: 08/23/2023. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
 
In a white-fronted Amazon parrot's primary enclosure, there was a piece of sheet metal flashing (approximately 4” wide) 
wrapped around the top of the nest box where the bird was actively climbing around on. The top edge of the metal was 
covered but the bottom edge was loose, leaving a visible gap (approximately 1/2" wide). Sharp edges can cause injury to 
the bird. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp 
edges that could injure the birds.  
Correct by: 8/27/2023. 
3.158(c) 
   
 
There were several discarded cages, farm equipment, and other discarded items on the grounds of the area near the 
maintenance sheds in the back area. The peacocks at the facility are free-roaming and have access to all areas. There 
were at least three peacocks observed walking or resting under these areas of clutter at the time of inspection. Discarded 
matter can cause injury to the free-ranging animals as well as serve as living areas for rodents and other pests. The 
facility must ensure the premises where housing facilities are located, including surrounding grounds, are kept clean to 
facilitate proper animal husbandry and sanitation. 
Correct by: 9/5/2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

Additional Inspectors: 
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Lynh Ly, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
